bestBHT.bht: Your consistent lives and faithful reproofs will be your 'armor of light' in making an inroad on the kingdom of darkness. The light of your Christian life, shed upon the deeds of darkness, will bring them out of the category of darkness into light. When you reprove, manifesting the hidden sins and evil works, everything that is made manifest becomes light. It is only through the light that the true moral quality of these things is revealed. So, turn on the light and let your reproofs be a means of bringing to light what is involved in darkness.

Henry Alford: the light of your Christian life, which will be by your reproof shed upon these deeds of darkness, will bring them out of the category of darkness into light
They themselves were thus ‘once darkness,’ but having been ‘reproved’ by God’s Spirit, had become ‘light in the Lord.’
when it is manifested it becomes light
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: when they are reproved...everything that is (that is, suffers
itself to be) made manifest (or 'shone upon,' namely, by your
The devil and the wicked will not suffer
themselves to be made manifest by the light, but love darkness,
though outwardly the light shines round them.
faithful reproofs will be your 'armor of light' in making an inroad on the kingdom of darkness.
Albert Barnes: Its true nature is demonstrated; that is, it is made known.
Light is the means of seeing what things are. We discern their form, nature, appearance by it.
That system which discloses the true nature of what is done by the pagan, deserves to be considered as 'light'; and that the gospel which does this, should be regarded as a system of light and truth.
Marvin Vincent: Whatsoever doth make manifest is light. [παν το φανερουμενον φως εστιν].
Manifestation is a law of good and evil alike.
By suffering the tares to grow, their difference from the wheat, which at first is not apparent, is fully revealed.
John Calvin: Evil works, which had been concealed, will stand out to public view, when they have been made manifest by the word of God.
It is Light, he says, which makes all things manifest; and hence it followed that they were unworthy of the name, if they did not bring to light what was involved in darkness.
Philip Schaff: The Apostle confirms his precept about reproof, by showing how the light wholesomely affects even these things which it is a shame to speak of.

All things, such as these secret sins, when they are reproved by you (as commanded in Ephesians 5:11) are made manifest by the light, their true moral quality is revealed by the light thus thrown upon them; only the light can do this, for everything which is made manifest is light.
'Light' is here used in a metaphorical (not in its ethical) sense. It is not asserted that a moral transformation necessarily results from this revealing process.
Archibald T. Robertson: Often the preacher is the only man brave enough to turn the light on the private sins of men and women or even those of a community.
John Gill: As all sins should be, by the ministers of the Gospel, and by other saints, and will be by God...either here or hereafter, for the punishment of them."

Either by the saints, who are made light in the Lord, and detect and reprove the sins of others; or by the word of the Lord, which discovers the heinousness of sins; or by Christ the light of the world, who as Judge will bring to light the hidden things of darkness."
This is true in things natural and spiritual, whether of the sun in the firmament, or of Christ the sun of righteousness; or of the divine word, or of good men.
John Wesley: But all things which are reproved, are thereby dragged out into the light, and made manifest - Shown in their proper colours, by the light.
For whatsoever doth make manifest is light - That is, for nothing but light, yea, light from heaven, can make anything manifest.
...nothing but light, yea, light from heaven, can make anything manifest.
